div1.head: Journal clipping, The Washington Jeffersonian, October, 1900
div1.p:

member of the old Washington literary so-
ciety and won the honor in essay on one
occasion in the inter-society contest. He
was one of the founders of the JEFFERSON-
IAN, and its first business manager. Mr.
Welshons always took much interest and
pride in his alma mater. and in recent years
has been one of our most loyal supporters of
college athletics. As a writer he had a style
peculiarly his own, and it was conceded
among all newspaper men of Pittsburg that
he had no superior there. His memory was
wonderful, and words and sentences came
to him without any trouble. His editorials
were gems, and his arguments could not be
well refuted. Sarcasm, wit and brilliancy
abounded in all of them as the occasion de-
manded. In politics he had also taken a
prominent part, successfully, too, in the
way of party work, He had worked on
nearly all the papers of Pittsburg, but prin-
cipally on the Times, and had also worked
for Philadelphia papers. Going to Pitts-
burg with no experience, he was turned
down by several newspapers, but it was not
long until all regretted that turning down,
and were anxious to employ him. One of
his greatest pieces of newspaper work was
in writing up the Johnstown flood for the
Times at a time when the wires were down
and there was no communication with that
point. Welshons knew every foot of the
flooded territory, and seated in the Time;
office wrote what turned out to be an accur-
ate description, and all the other newspa-
pers wondered how the Times had “scoop-
ed” them.

'89--An official telegram from Cuba con-
veys the sad intelligence of the death of Dr.
Jesse W. Lazear, a young physician of great
promise, in whom the citizens of Washing-
ton and Western Pennsylvania feel an
unusual interest. After leaving college he
entered the Johns Hopkins University,
graduating from the medical department
with high honors. A year spent abroad
still further fitted him for the practice of his
noble profession. Last spring by appoint-
ment of the United States government he,
in company with two other physicians, went
to Cuba to make a critical study of that
dread scourge of the tropics, yellow fever,
to which he has fallen a victim. Some
years since he was united in marriage to
Miss Mabel Houstman, a native of the state
of California, who survives him together
with two children. His family had accom-
panied him on his visit to Cuba. Dr. La-
zear comes of an old and honored Pennsyl-
vania family, his grandfather being the Hon.
Jesse Lazear, of Uniontown. His father
was William Lazear. T. C. Lazear, Esq.,
of Pittsburg, is an uncle. His untimely
death is a loss to the profession of medicine,
to which he was most devoted. He as
truly died for mankind and his country as if
he had fallen in the din of battle while fol-
lowing the flag. His wife and children have
the sympathy of an appreciative country.

'60--David Acheson McKnight, of Wash-
ington, D. C., died at his home in the
National Capital, Saturday, October 13,
aged 57 years. Mr. McKnight was the son
of Jas. McKnight, a prominent iron founder
of Pittsburg, in which city he was born in
1843. He chose the law as his profession
and in it attained a position of eminence.

'99--John L. Stewart has severed his
connection with the Observer, and has left
for Cambridge, Mass., for the purpose of
entering the law department of Harvard
university.

'97--Dr. Jno. R. McCurdy, of Mononga-
hela, of the medical staff at the West Penn
hospital, was a recent visitor of Washington
friends.

'99--Ralph M. Allison, of Wade avenue,
has entered upon his second year's studies
at the University of Pennsylvania.

'99--Homer K. Underwood, of Washing-
ton, has matriculated at Harvard as a post-
graduate student.

'95--Samuel J. Orr, of Greenville, pass-
ed a successful examination for admission
to the Mercer county bar.
